canvases.label: The Antiquities of Athens Measured and Delineated, pl.XIV

metadata.value: The Antiquities of Athens Measured and Delineated
metadata.label: Title

metadata.value: The Engraver James Stuart, often known as James "Athenian" Stuart, partnered with long-time friend Nicholas Revett to create a new accurate description of the antiquities of Greece as they stood at the time. This project consisted of a trip to Athens to see the works at hand, producing the illustrations first in gouache style and then later into black and white engravings for the publication. This engraving is of a freeze from the second volume of The Antiquities of Athens Measured and Delineated. It is of "...the remaining part of the freeze immediatley under the Soffit or Ceiling of the Peripterus..." Stuart's efforts to document the now fragmented decoration of the Parthenon and other like buildings was not the first but was a start of intense study of the ruins of Athens as they were at modern times. Even though Stuart spent much more time living and studying in Rome, he is best known for his time spent in Greece and contribution to Greek Revival.
metadata.label: Description

canvases.label: The Antiquities of Athens Measured and Delineated, pl.XII

metadata.value: The Antiquities of Athens Measured and Delineated
metadata.label: Title

metadata.value: The Engraver James Stuart, often known as James "Athenian" Stuart, partnered with long-time friend Nicholas Revett to create a new accurate description of the antiquities of Greece as they stood at the time. This project consisted of a trip to Athens to see the works at hand, producing the illustrations first in gouache style and then later into black and white engravings for the publication. These two engravings are of friezes from the second volume of The Antiquities of Athens Measured and Delineated. The description of the two from the text goes as, "All the Metopes in the Freeze (in number 92) have likewise been enriched with sculpture; those on the fourth side had each a group of two figures, representing a centaur combating a Lapitha; a few of these reamin, and I have given three plates to them, numbered X, XI, and XII; They are in Alto Relievo, most of them miserably broken, though not so entirely defaced as those on the Metopes of the northern side and the two fronts." Stuart's efforts to document the now fragmented decoration of the Parthenon and other like buildings was not the first but was a start of intense study of the ruins of Athens as they were at modern times. Even though Stuart spent much more time living and studying in Rome, he is best known for his time spent in Greece and contribution to Greek Revival.
metadata.label: Description
